div1.p: LEGATION DE BELGIQUE Washington, 19 Juillet 1890

Monsieur l'administrateur général, Répondant à la lettre que vous avez bien voulu m'adresser sous la date du 21 juin dernier, no 944 j'ai l'honneur de vous faire savoir que M. James S. Whiting de Boston est un jeune homme d'environ 25 ans, employé dans un magasin de cuirs. On ne lui connait pas d'autres ressources et il n'a aucune position dans le monde des affaires.
M. Gill, consul de Belgique à Boston,
Monsieur Van Eetvelde administrateur Gl du Département des Affaires Etrangeres du Congo.

recommande pour le poste de Consul de l'Etat Indépendant du Congo au cette ville, M. John F. Brooks, no 103 State Street. C'est un grand négociait à la tête d'une importante maison qui s'occupe spécialement du commerce avec la côte africaine.
Il faut dire toutefois que M. Brooks a acquis sa grande fortune par l'exportation des liqueurs sur cette côte.

Les journaux ont signalé la possibilité de l'établissement d'une ligne de navigation entre Boston et la côte africaine, mais il n'est pas question, pour le moment, de la réalisation de ce projet. On ne pense pas que le commerce avec le Congo puisse être suffisant pour engager à l'établiss- ement de cette ligne avant l'ouverture
du chemin de fer.
Veuillez agréer, Monsieur l'Adminis- trateur Général, l'assurance de ma consideration la plus distinguée.
Mr. Leghait Ministre de Belgique, Washington

Dec. 26. 1889. 82 High St., Boston, Mass. USA
His Excellency, Governor of the Congo Free State.

In view of the fact that in a short time a considerable trade will be carried on between this country, and especially from this port, and the Congo Free State, I take the liberty to apply to your Excel- lency for the position of Consul.

There is already some prospect of a steamship line being established and between Boston and the Congo. If this project is carried into effect I think that your Excellency will need a representation in this section of the United States.
I have the honor of being, very respectfully, Your obedient servant, () J. S. Whiting
LEGATION OF BELGIUM Washington, July 19 1890

Mister Administrator General, Responding to the letter that you addressed to me under the date June 21 of last, no 944 I have the honor to inform you that Mr. James S. Whiting of Boston is a young man of around 25 years, employed in a shop of leathers. We do not know him from other resources and he has no position in the world of affairs.
Mr. Gill, consul of Belgium in Boston,
Mister Van Eetvelde administrator Gl of the Department of Foreign Affairs of the Congo.

recommends for the post of Consul of the Independent State of the Congo in this city, Mr. John F. Brooks, no 103 State Street. He is a big merchant at the head of an important house that takes care especially of the commerce with the African coast.
It must be said nevertheless that Mr. Brooks acquired his large fortune by the exportation of liquors on this coast.

The journals signaled the possibility of the establishment of a line of navigation between Boston and the african coast, but it is not question, for the moment, of the fulfillment of this project. We do not think that the commerce with the Congo could be sufficient to engage in the establish- ment of this line before the opening
of the railroad.
Please accept, Mister Adminis- trator General, the assurance of my most distinguished consideration.
Mr. Leghait Minister of Belgium, Washington
Brussels, June 21 1890

our consul.

Mr. J. S. Whiting does not indicate, , any reference. On the occasion, I would be charmed to know if this consul has some ground.
I thank you, Mister Minister, for that which you will do for him for the of the Congo in this , .
